title: IRS Staff and Audits: the More, the Merrier?
sub_head: More work without more funds leaves the IRS no option but to cut back on answering the telephone and auditing the wealthy.
body:
In “The $1 Trillion Tax Evasion Opportunity” (Politics & Ideas, April 21), William A. Galston makes it sound like there is $1 trillion sitting in a cave somewhere. If the government hires 5,000 Internal Revenue Service sleuths and finds it, then we can pay for some of President Biden’s giveaway. But the $1 trillion isn’t in a hiding place. It is in the pockets of millions of Americans. They use it to spend, spurring the economy. Transferring that $1 trillion to the government may not be an improvement.
F.A. D’Ambrosio
Concord, Mass.

Mr. Galston cites Charles O. Rossotti’s plan to collect more in taxes. Mr. Rossotti was the first IRS commissioner in a long time who was not a tax professional. He was a successful businessman who ran the IRS like a business, not a bureaucracy. Lawmakers should pay close attention to what he has to say.
